Article.ArticleTitle: Ozonation of biologically-treated municipal solid waste leachate using an integrated process of O<sub>3</sub>/Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> and microbubble reactor.

AbstractText: The ozonation process was limited by the relatively low solubility in liquid and low transfer mass efficiency. In this work, O<sub>3</sub>/Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> was adopted to treat biologically-treated municipal solid waste (MSW) leachate in a microbubble gas-liquid reactor. The residual COD concentration is meeting the discharge standard after treatment. The effects of operating parameters such as Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> dosage, external reactor pressure, liquid temperature, inlet ozone concentration and ozone flow rate on COD removal and mineralization (TOC removal) were studied systematically. This process was able to remove 89.86% of COD, 65.35% of TOC and 92.12% of UV-254 under the optimal conditions. And the intensification mechanism of O<sub>3</sub>/Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> system was explored through analysing the change of UV-254, 3D-EEM and the organic matters present in the leachate.
